txt.en: 'How true fly the arrows that none can see?'
'The report of your skill impresses me not.'
'You see much, [placeholder]. Few folk understand the truth of it.'
Hildegard is inside the cave of Orlag Den, where she makes her home.
'You speak sparingly of your deeds, but I can see their extent and it is vast.'
'But I need no report to know of your prowess, for I have seen it from afar.'
'Is it a gift to know what comes? Or is it a burden?'
'The good folk you fight to protect would sing your praises, were they here.'
'I cannot choose what I see, and often it fills me with fear and sorrow.'
'You have been their shining shield in the darkness, and will be again.'
'You have learned the value of speaking little, but saying much.'
Hildegard has asked you what adventuring discipline you follow.
'I know you for a master of language, a keeper of cryptic runes.'
'You study ancient sigils and take from them valuable knowledge.'
'Good folk of all lands will need your knowledge to stand against the darkness that comes.'
'You remain silent, but still I can tell much about you.'
'You are a captain, a leader of Men, and inspire them by your example.'
'Any could look at [placeholder] and see a skilled burglar. This is no difficult thing.'
'I know this, too: they will have need of your leadership in the dark days ahead.'
'I see that you know wisdom. It is unseemly to boast.'
'Study the mysteries, master of lore, and you will find knowledge.'
'It waits for you under sun and moon and stars, even as evil beckons.'
Herubrand has brought you to Orlag Den, the cave of the soothsayer Hildegard.
'When a line of such wardens defend a position, there must be a tumult of boasting!'
'Perhaps not. Perhaps the others know to speak instead with spear and lance.'
'The finest in all the land, you say?'
'Did you inherit pride and boastfulness from Beorn as well?'
'But I know your skill with such weapons, and the courage with which you wield them.'
'I know the truth of your gift, Hildegard. My people are well-versed in such mysteries.'
'Such boasting perhaps explains the number of brawls in which you find yourself!'
'I think Beorn himself would consider you a mere pup in deeds.'
'You will have need of that skill in the days to come, for darkness approaches.'
'Horn simply does not understand.'
Talk to Herubrand inside Orlag Den
'I know your heart longs for the Sea, though the people you must help remain on land.'
'And yet the power in you may give you cause to boast, in time.'
'You will have need of your skills in the days ahead.'
Talk to Hildegard in Orlag Den
Answer Hildegard's questions, and hear what she has to say
Follow Herubrand to meet the soothsayer Hildegard
Listen to the soothsayer Hildegard
'You remain silent, but still I can tell much about you.'
'You are a master of language and cryptic words, a keeper of runes.'
'You study the sigils left by ancient peoples and master their secrets.'
'The good folk will need your knowledge to stand against the approaching evil.'
'There is no far-seeing here. You see things no more clearly than the rest of us.'
'Any who look at [placeholder] with eyes could guess this. It is no mystery.'
'You speak in riddles. Anyone can do that.'
'Any may speak in riddles. There is no far-sight here.'
'This takes no special sight to see.'
'You speak in riddles to mask the truth. This is no great power.'
'Any who look at [placeholder] could report thus. This is no mystery.'
'It takes no far-sight to see this. Even I can see that is true!'
'This is an easy foretelling to make. Even I could say such a thing!'
'You remain silent, but you cannot hide your deeds from me.'
'You are a champion, and well-known to good folk throughout the land.'
'The bite of your weapons is known to the foe-men you dispatch.'
'Any who see [placeholder] could say this. It takes no far-sight to see.'
'What is it, Hildegard?'
'I have battles to fight. They will not wait.'
'Horn!'
'Hildegard, what is it?'
'Horn!'
'What else do you see?'
'No!'
'The finest in all the land, or perhaps in all the Sea, you say?'
'Hildegard, what can we do?'
'Such boasting perhaps explains why you must sail away so often!'
'Hildegard!'
'DNT - Blah!'
'DNT - Blah! Belief!'
'You are of the line of Beorn, and well-known to good folk throughout the land.'
'[placeholder], do you believe in my gift?'
'I believe you are a skin-changer, able to change your form as Beorn himself did.'
'Come here, girl.'
'You kindle, child.'
'It tells me that you see only what the rest of us do, and no more.'
'Be silent, foolish man.'
'It will be some time yet. That is the way of it.'
'You remain silent, but still I can tell much about you.'
'I cannot say.'
'You sing songs of inspiration to bolster the spirits of your fellows, and they fight on.'
'You remain silent, but I know this.'
'Have you heard the tale of Wyrgende, doubting one?'
'Their defeats are short-lived, much like the foes they face on their return.'
'Your fists speak for you, and they speak loudly on behalf of those who cannot.'
'Do you believe it?'
'Without your songs of hope and perseverance, they would fall.'
'That is a worthy use for your skills.'
'I see a great battle.'
'A vast army marches outside the walls.'
'Is this far-sight, then? The speaking of plain truths that anyone can see?'
'This is no far-sight. Any who look at [placeholder] could tell this.'
'I see a white horse, penned by shadows.'
'It takes no far-sight to say such things. Even I can see it!'
'Your love lies upon the broken ground, his shield shattered.'
'I see death!'
'The list of the dead is long. The minstrels mourn.'
'You remain silent, but still I can tell much about you.'
'Such a foretelling could be made of any burglar! This is no difficult thing.'
'A burglar of great skill, you creep through shadows and pass locked doors.'
'Any who see [placeholder] could tell this. There is no mystery in it.'
'From these places thought sealed, you remove treasures and secrets.'
'Your skills will be called upon in the days ahead.'
'These are no new tidings. Any could look at [placeholder] and foretell this.'
'Any who look at [placeholder] with eyes could see it. This is no mystery.'
'Do you restore the hope of your friends, or bolster your own reputation?'
'You remain silent, but I still can tell much about you.'
'A true minstrel sings for, and of, others.
'You seek knowledge in the places where once it dwelt: ruins and caves of yesterday.'
'When days are dark, you will inspire their hearts with songs of victory and hope.'
'The wisdom you seek is sought by others who covet the secrets of the past.'
'You are a master of lore, and must guard yourself from the corruption it offers.'
'Humility suits you, but I know of your great skill aboard ship.'
'And I know your heart longs for the Sea, though the people you must help remain on land.'
'They are aided by it, and that is to your credit.'
'Do you inspire your fellows by boasting of your own deeds?'
'A captain of Men should lead by shining example.'
'There will be great need for you to lead in the days ahead.'
'How can you manage to pilfer anything while so quick to boast of your exploits?'
'It is a wonder you can remain silent enough to stealthily creep anywhere!'
'And yet I know your skills, for they are as plain to me as moonlight on the river.'
'You will have cause to use them in service of good folk in the days to come.'
'Any who look at [placeholder] with eyes could guess this. It is no mystery.'
'Are all such as you so rude as this?'
Instance: The Soothsayer
'You are a hunter of great skill, [placeholder]. It is not unseemly to say so.'
'Your arrows fly true and hit even the smallest of marks.'
'You will save many folk from death with the contents of a single quiver.'
'Be not shy around me, humble champion.'
'The good folk for whom you fight would fill my ears with tale of your deeds.'
'You remain silent, but I know what you are without words.'
'They are not here, but I see the valour of which you wish not to speak.'
'You are a hunter of great skill. If you loose an arrow, it hits its mark.'
'You will face great evils from afar, and shower death upon them.'
'I do not know which is the wider: your shield or the story you make of it.'
'The truest defender speaks only when necessary, and then sparingly.'
'But I see that you care for those you protect, and would fall in battle before them if you must.'
'Mind your feet. She is accustomed to the dark, as we are not.'
'Remember, friends: be courteous.'
'But it is a gift, Hildegard. With this sight I could set many things aright.'
'Hildegard, I have returned. Am I welcome?'
'I am not alone, Hildegard.'
'No, I bring friends from afar.'
'Your discourtesy shames you, Horn!'
'I did not bring you before Hildegard so you might insult the woman.'
'Horn, wait!'
'You are in good company, [placeholder], to share your friend's disbelief.'
'Such a foretelling is easy to make. Even I could say such a thing!'
'You wish not to boast? Must I look to other minstrels to learn of your skill?'
'Do all rune-keepers speak so highly of themselves?'
'No. The bard with the most impact lets the song sing for itself.'
'I have seen enough in this world to know the truth of your gift, Hildegard.'
'The true course of wisdom is to speak sparingly.'
'That tells me much.'
'My people are well-versed in such mysteries.'
'I chide but gently, for I know you have delved into the mysteries, and know much.'
'I thank you for the kindness, [placeholder].'
'[placeholder] and Horn simply do not understand.'
'Good folk of all lands will have need of this knowledge, for dark days approach.'
'Most of my kinsmen do not believe in such things.'
'Herubrand is unusual in that regard, and in others.'
Talk to Nona in Orlag Den
'Any could say this after but a single glance at [placeholder].'
Hildegard stands, unblinking, but does not appear to see you any longer
Talk to Hildegard in Orlag Den
Answer Hildegard's questions, and hear what she has to say
Listen to the words of Hildegard
Talk to Horn in Orlag Den
Listen to Horn and Hildegard's confrontation
'You remain silent, but I still can tell much about you.'
'This is no far-seeing. Any could say such a thing.'
'You are a warden, and never give up ground you wish to hold.'
'There will be no lack of need for you in the days to come.'
'The cities of good folk come under threat. They will turn to you to hold the line 'gainst evil.'
'There is much wisdom in the world, but it comes not to those who boast.'
'Humility suits you, but I know the number of your brawls.'
'Study the mysteries and look not for praise, and you will have wisdom.'
'And I know how often you fight on behalf of those who cannot.'
'You will find knowledge, even as the skies darken and evil beckons.'
'It is a worthy use for your skills.'
'You remain silent, but you cannot hide your deeds from me.'
'I know you for a staunch defender of the Free People, a guardian of good folk.'
'Your shield guards those who cannot shield themselves.'
'Any could say this. [placeholder]'s skill with the bow is easy to see.'
'This is no gift of far-sight. Any who see [placeholder] could say these things.'
'Which speaks more loudly? The deeds or your report of them?'
'Keep your weapons sharp, and they will speak for the both of you.'
'Still I see great victories for you in the days to come.'
'Is this all a soothsayer needs: an ability to speak cryptically of plain things?'
'Any could say this of [placeholder] and be not wrong. There is no far-seeing here.'
'Any who see [placeholder] could tell this. There is no far-seeing here.'
'You could say this of anyone, and it might prove true.'
'Ah, young Herubrand, you are welcome at any time.'
Horn has made his disbelief of Hildegard most plain.
'Your visits brighten these dark days.'
'You bring your son, Herefara? He speaks sparingly, but he too is welcome.'
'Ah. Let them approach and introduce themselves.'
DNT - Blah!

'I cannot believe Horn would act this way, [placeholder]! Has he closed his eyes to everything we have experienced on this journey? He shares the maddening outlook of his people! Suvulch will not understand him.'

Nona clenches her fists and tosses her hair in frustration.

'We cannot choose to whom we give our hearts, [placeholder]. That is our lot, but I might have chosen one less stubborn, from out of all the kingdoms of Men!'
'Much that you have done is already known to me.'
'You speak of your skills the same way you exercise them: with quiet confidence.'
'But there is much ahead of you I cannot see.'
DNT - Blah!
'But I know the extent of your prowess in burglary, and it is wide indeed.'
'May I ask what adventuring discipline you call your own?'
'You pass locked doors as if they were mere mist, removing both treasure and secrets.'
'What is your name, doubting one?'
'Your prowess speaks for itself, humble warden.'
'Worry not, Herubrand. I am not offended by disbelief.'
Listen to Horn's confrontation with Hildegard in Orlag Den.
'DNT - Blah!'
'I know you hold the line against evil, and defend good folk in all lands.'
'I know too that you will be called upon to do so in the dark days ahead.'
Nona is in Orlag Den, the cave of the soothsayer Hildegard.

'[placeholder], what can we do? If Hildegard speaks the truth, it means Horn will fall in battle. A good death for any warrior, but he is not just any warrior, [placeholder]. He is mine, and it is not glory he seeks. I know this to be true!\n\n'I will keep Horn from meeting this end. Others have fought their fates. Why not Nona, daughter of Suvulch, sister of Wadu? You will help me in this, [placeholder]. You will say none of this to Horn. Do you understand?'

'We have arrived, [placeholder]. Hildegard has sight of many things still to come, and the source of her power is unknown to me. Many of my kinsmen call it witchcraft, sorcery such as that practiced by the Elves, but I say Hildegard was a woman of Rohan, and remains so.\n\n'Speak to her with courtesy.'

You give Hildegard your name and she nods.\n\n'It is a pleasure to meet you, friend of Herubrand. Many are the roads you have walked to get here, and many more you will walk before you are at last given rest.'
Hildegard stares sightlessly forward.
Hildegard stands, unblinking, but does not appear to see you or Nona any longer.

'This woman speaks in riddles and rubbish, [placeholder]. If she has knowledge of days to come, why does she not spell it for us plain? Were she to do that perhaps I would give her my belief, but until then I remain unconvinced.'
Hildegard has asked to speak with Nona.
Horn is in Orlag Den, the cave of the soothsayer Hildegard.
'It is no secret to me why you inspire such confidence in those you lead.'
'This you know already: a true captain of Men leads by example.'
'The days ahead will test your resolve and your leadership, humble captain.'
'Is this all a soothsayer needs: an ability to speak cryptically of plain things?'
'Should you not already know my name?'
'She burns with the heat of battle!'
'You say you can see the events of days to come?'
'Tell me what awaits me, and prove your claim is true.'
'I thought as much.'
'There is no straight path through this life.'
'Of course. All children of Rohan have heard it.'
Hildegard looks at you curiously. Her face is a quiet mask, and you cannot tell what hides behind her calm expression.
'I have sung the tale myself a dozen times, at the least.'
Hildegard looks at you curiously. Her face is a quiet mask, and you cannot tell what hides behind her calm expression.
'I will not be tricked by this woman. I will wait for you outside.'
The soothsayer Hildegard stands upright, staring forward sightlessly. She still breathes, but she no longer appears to see either you or Nona.
'Be not shy around me, humble Beorning.'
'The good folk for whom you fight would fill my ears with tale of your deeds.'
'I see the strength of Beorn in you.'
Herubrand is inside Orlag Den, the cave of the soothsayer Hildegard.
